529293829.name: everybody comes to Revolucion
529293829.author: a TripAdvisor user
529293829.reviewBody: Avenida Revolucion is a big part of the reason for Tijuana\'s reputation. The casual tourist sees what everyone knows. But Tijuana is very much more than a tourist trap. It is a thriving metropolis, and Revolucion is its hub. The street contains many surprises. One of my favorites is Cafe Prague, or Cafe Praha, a European-inspired place that serves Continental foods and desserts. Located between 4th and 4th Streets on the east side of the avenue, it gives the impression of a world apart. Another more traditional place is Sanborn\'s department store, between 8th & 9th, also on the east side of the street. Sanborn\u00b4s is anything but a tourist mecca; in its excellent restaurant, you will rub shoulders with prosperous locals. The whole avenue is chock full of interesting boutiques, not a few of them presided over by shopkeepers who will call out to you in the charming local fashion. My wife, who is Japanese and not easy to impress, says she feels more at ease in Tijuana than in central San Diego. When she says it she\u00b4s thinking of Revolucion, which is easygoing and welcoming under its sometimes garish appearance.

529284197.name: You say you want a Revolution? This is a bit tired
529284197.author: a TripAdvisor user
529284197.reviewBody: A bit tired, a bit clich\u00e9d but I guess a magnet in the evening or the entertainment and the \'fun\'. Cheap souvenirs, live donkeys and tonnes of leather just about sums it up.

529264875.name: Main Attraction of Tijuana
529264875.author: a TripAdvisor user
529264875.reviewBody: the main tourist draw of tijuana is about 8 blocks wide and a kilometer long and is lined with what else but shops, bars, and restaurants, street vendors, street food stalls and a lot more which are mainly aimed at tourists. There are some good shops along Revolucion but mostly they are little more than cheesy souvenir shops. There are a few "fixed price" shops as you walk south on Revolucion, \n\nthe Avenida de Revolucion has it\'s share of the bizzare and odd hehehe. Avenida de Revolucion is lined with shops, bars, and restaurants, many aimed at tourists hence this center of tijuana is a certified tourist trap hehehe. This is what most day-trippers to Tijuana experience, and it should go without saying that Revolucion is not representative of Tijuana and certainly not of Mexico.

529168630.name: A great alternative to going deep into Mexico. We take the trolly from San Diego that goes right to the border and you j
529168630.author: a TripAdvisor user
529168630.reviewBody: We have found Tijuana to be very safe, great place to shop for whatever you are looking for and the prices are MUCH less than coastal tourist cities.

526773794.name: Visiting Tijuana at night time
526773794.author: a TripAdvisor user
526773794.reviewBody: Flew into LAX at 9:30PM, drove down to San Diego parked the car rental in San Ysidro. Walked over to Tijuana at 2AM. Cab driver in Tijuana asked my friend and I need a cab ride to Hong Kong? We looked at each other not know where that is, but said "Sure". How much is the cab ride? Taxi driver said "5 USD". Great! Partied until 6AM, took the taxi ride back to the boarder. Walked into U.S side of the boarder. Crazy!! \nI wouldn\'t recommend folks going into Tijuana at night time. Not by yourself. However, if you want to park your car at Jack in the Box in San Yisdro or a parking lot across from Jack in the Box. It is about 8 bucks for 10 hrs. \nCrossing over from U.S to Mexico is pretty easy. Just have your passport. From U.S walk about 10 mins, you will see Mexico boarder agent, so him/her you passport. Then walk about 10 more minutes where you will see cab drivers in Mexico. Tell him that you want to be drop off at "Hong Kong Bar". Cost about 5 USD. Cost is the same when driving back to US boarder.

526628583.name: Authentic Mexican Market/swap meet
526628583.author: a TripAdvisor user
526628583.reviewBody:
A general swap meet where you can purchase authentic Mexican toys, food, or clothes. When you are looking to buy things you need to make sure you do not get ripped off. These people try to over charge if they assume that you are from the united states. The food around here is great and to give you a better understanding a beer here might cost you 1.50$ as to a beer in SD for 7.50$ same exact beer. 

We also had a horrible experience where the people with the donkeys tried to give us a hard time for only wanting to take pictures with our phone rather than purchase it from them. We wanted to just give them 10$ instead of purchasing the picture for 20$ since we did not use their materials. An easy transaction turned into a mess and that is just because they were trying to make every penny possible off americans. 

Overall love the place just be careful when buying things.

526431396.name: Very Touristy Place for Americans
526431396.author: a TripAdvisor user
526431396.reviewBody: The main drag for American visitors. Nothing of real interest unless you just want to be entertained the way Mexicans think Americans want to be entertained. There is so much more to do and see in Tijuana. \n\nThe only thing of real importance along Avenida Revolucion is Caesars Restaurant, supposedly where the "Caesar Salad" was invented. They prepare it table side and it is quite THE spectacle. And yes, it tastes better than any Caesar salad you\'ll get anywhere else. Great service and reasonable prices overall. It will compensate for the silly (and sorry) zebra painted donkeys you\'ll be confronted with as "photo opp\'s" along the avenue.

524701686.name: Cheap prices but not like before
524701686.author: a TripAdvisor user
524701686.reviewBody: I found cheap prices but cheap quality. Pushy vendors. Some of the artwork was good though, and cheap. The night clubs are no good; not even close to what they used to be in the 90s. After the drug violence died down, tourism seems to be coming back here slowly. Hopefully this area makes a full recovery.

524407551.name: Safe
524407551.author: a TripAdvisor user
524407551.reviewBody: Revolution is a safe place for visitors to shop, eat, and get a feel of Mexico. There are many shops with great souvenir items. Of course the shop owners will bother you a little and want to negotiate on price, but that is the Mexico experience. This area is heavily patrolled and safe during the day time. They know if something happens to a tourist, they all will lose.\n  Just a quick $5 cab ride from the border. I do not recommend walking since there is a few questionable streets between the border and this area. \n  It is different than the States, and it should be. That is part of the experience. Eat at Caesars, or there is good Italian at Guiseppes. And of course there is Yahoo stands everywhere.

523990393.name: Good for tourists
523990393.author: a TripAdvisor user
523990393.reviewBody: Came here on a tour from San Diego & had a good few hours visiting the restaurants, bars & shops. It does look a little run down & yes people came up to us trying to sell things, but we never felt bothered or unsafe. Enjoyable place to visit & lots of great food & drink. \nGot through customs to Mexico in 10mins & back to the US in about 30mins.

522109477.name: Very busy Street
522109477.author: a TripAdvisor user
522109477.reviewBody: Well what can I say about this Street you can find absolutely everything and anything you may need from a good restaurants to nice artesanias and everything in between expect a lot of people maybe just not suitable for little kids because all the bars and prostitutes every single corner other than that if you go with just adults that is the place to go

521577075.name: Third-World Dump!
521577075.author: a TripAdvisor user
521577075.reviewBody:
I've lived in San Diego for over 50 years.  On Labor Day I went to Tijuana for the first time since I was 5 years old.  I took the Trolley to the border and crossed on foot.  Then I walked to Avenida Revolucion.

Everything is dirty and run down.  There is trash in the streets and gitters.  On the walk to Avenenida Revolucion you walk a bridge crossing a river.  The river is filthy with trash. There are even poor souls living under the bridge.  You'll be bothered several times each block to come into a shop or a restaurant, or to have your picture taken with a donkey.  There's at least one pharmacy every block touting viagra.  There's tons of souvenir shops selling junk.  There's some decent looking restaurants.  But the surroundings are so depressing I didn't eat at any of them.

It's really, really depressing there.  It feels safe enough, but after 2 hours I had seen enough. Don't believe the hype about Tijuana being some sort of "arts and crafts" center.   

Crossing back into the US took two hours.  There was a long line to get back through Customs.  You'll get pestered by people trying to sell you stuff the whole time you wait in line to cross....people selling gum, candy, cheap guitars, hats, bread, cab rides, charity organizations and beggars.  It's really depressing.

We've been to some nice places in Mexico e.g. Cabo San Lucas, Matzatlan, Cancun, others.  But Tijuana is not like those places.  It's like a giant slum. 

I can't think of any reason to ever return to Tijuana unless it's for the culture shock.

518545801.name: Restaurants, souvenirs everywhere
518545801.author: a TripAdvisor user
518545801.reviewBody: After taking the san diego trolley, we walked across the border. We took a taxi to downtown Tijuana. The city is not what I expected. It was very dirty. Maybe at night its overlooked but daytime very busy and dirty. Many opportunities to shop and eat. I didn\'t want to eat anything. As soon as you sat down, small kids would come up and try to sell you souvenirs. Even after saying no, the kids were relentless. It was eye opening but not anything I\'d ever have to do again.

513847708.name: Revitalized and Thriving again
513847708.author: a TripAdvisor user
513847708.reviewBody: With my first visit over 50 years ago, shoeless children selling chicles and polaroid cameras for tourists with sombrero on a painted zonkey, and everyone selling the worst tequila on the planet in a Cuervo Gold bottle it had a unique wild west  ot third world charm.  Then the complete collapse in 2008 - 201.\nFast forward to today with only vestiges of that history visible and a rebirth of pure Mexican spirit in the restaurants cantinas and shops.  Wonderful, and yes, you may still find a photographer with a zonkey too!

507941786.name: La Revo
507941786.author: a TripAdvisor user
507941786.reviewBody: I have been coming here for many years since my wife is from Tijuana, I have seen this street evolve and I am happy to say that the changes are for good, they are focusing more on the tourist and are increasing police presence at night.. on this street u can find good restaurants, night clubs, bars, Pharmacies and many other shops.. I would still recommend for people to visit in groups because let\'s be honest Tijuana still dangerous at night and even more so if u are alone so as much as possible stay with a group u are less likely to be a victim of theft if u do.  If u do that and avoid dark alleys u will have a great time..in TJ.

506017452.name: Walking on history
506017452.author: a TripAdvisor user
506017452.reviewBody: This is one of the main streets of Tijuana. You can find restaurants, souvenirs, "zebras" and yes a lot of people. You can walk from the US -Mex border or take a bus or a taxi.

504840926.name: Must
504840926.author: a TripAdvisor user
504840926.reviewBody: If you visit this city you will find this Ave full of life specially over the weekend. Know to locals as La Revu  Full of bars and places to dance and eat. House of the burro zebra. Beware of the street signage if you are driving. Most of crossing streets are one way only. 2nd street can get a bit chaotic at times with traffic and pedestrians other wise have fun and enjoy.

502477584.name: Nice
502477584.author: a TripAdvisor user
502477584.reviewBody: The avenue is nice to buy souvenirs. A bit overpriced but can still find since good deals. We visited on a short trip to Tijuana. Good was great.

501119546.name: Tourist Central
501119546.author: a TripAdvisor user
501119546.reviewBody: This street is the main tourist street of all of Tijuana.  However, in the past 5 years or so it has had some significant changes providing some more cultural tastes of Tijuana as the tourist industry had declined and a revival toward local culture rose.  Certainly there is the Aztec indian dancers, the mariachis and souvenir shops but there are also interesting restaurants, bars and even an international theatre.  Enjoy the tourist gems like getting a picture on a burro-zebra but also appreciate some of the great cafes and restaurants offered as well.

498540957.name: Worth Doing Once
498540957.author: a TripAdvisor user
498540957.reviewBody:
On a family holiday to San Diego and wanted to experience Mexico quickly and easily so decided to head down to Tijuana.
It is very easy to do from the heart of San Diego, by just hopping on a trolley to San Ysidro which is basically the last stop on the line - it's the Blue line that you take (red trolley). You also need to buy a day pass at the station which cost around $7 for an adult but will last the whole day. The ride is about 20 minutes and when you hop off at San Ysidro you are virtually next to the border crossing - just follow the crowd or ask someone if you can't see the walkway. Tip - if you get to San Ysidro and change your mind last minute- dont stress , head over to the Las Americas premium outlets which are a ten minute walk from the station and shop instead - the trolley ride wasn't wasted! 

Now I must admit that I was a little nervous about this trip, particularly with two teenage girls tagging along, but overall it was pretty good. It's the usual process of be smart and don't invite problems. We got over the border without issue (don't forget your passports) and followed the advise by grabbing a taxi when we exited the other side (they are everywhere). We were going to revolution square to do a bit of souvenir hunting, have lunch and experience Mexico. The cost of the taxi (which I Pre checked with the driver before hopping in) was $8. The drive there was about 5 easy minutes and I gave the driver $10.

Once at Revolution Square it's basically a long walk up one side of the road and then back down the other. You will be invited into every shop by every seller and also encouraged to take a photo with those donkeys painted up to look like Zebra's. there are some very cool souvenirs so we basically browsed through a few shops and picked up a few gifts for ourselves and the people back home. We also stopped for some lunch which wasn't bad and was very cheap ($20 for the four of us).

When you have had enough of donkeys and souvenirs grab a taxi at the end of the road and ask them to take you back to the US boarder. This was probably the worst part of the trip as we waited for about two hours on a pretty hot day in a queue that was only partly covered. There are also a lot of street kids, disabled and old homeless people who beg, and sell things along the queue and the adjoining freeway, so you need to be accepting of this. 

Overall I am glad we went and it was a good experience for the family. From what I saw there is really nothing to be worried about (during the day anyway). Having said that once is enough for me.

498272369.name: Decent
498272369.author: a TripAdvisor user
498272369.reviewBody: Great area for shopping and good deals. A bit run down. We find it safe and convenient to shop and look around. Great deals!! Busy too and parking not easy but available.

498224345.name: Good street vendor location, safe and good feel to it
498224345.author: a TripAdvisor user
498224345.reviewBody: The vendors along the street have plenty of Mexico souvenirs. Several outdoor restaurants with very good food and drinks. Had Margaritas and food at one of them and besides the food being good there were plenty of guys with guitars and strolling around to serenade you or folks around you. This was early evening\nWalked up and down many streets in the area and all felt safe.

497381449.name: Pretty interesting..
497381449.author: a TripAdvisor user
497381449.reviewBody: Took a little stroll with 4 friends and did some sight seeing and people watching..... There is lots of it.. Not the cleanest part of town but felt safe. The arch is pretty cool.

497003725.name: Fun!
497003725.author: a TripAdvisor user
497003725.reviewBody: Fun to bargain with the sellers...got most my gifts here!! Stopped at corner bar for margerita....was alot of fun getting that "Mexican experience"!!

496987402.name: Visit after a long work day
496987402.author: a TripAdvisor user
496987402.reviewBody: Came here to shop for souvenirs and have a quick drink after a long day at work.  As long as you are walking in a group you can feel safe here.  Many shops to visit.  Bargains galore but don\'t expect to find a great deal but can bargain some on the prices.  Was a nice night out so walking and checking the sights out was nice.

492432785.name: Lovely for a stroll
492432785.author: a TripAdvisor user
492432785.reviewBody: Nice to walk,... lots of souvenir stores, prices are uniform so there is less rip off. If you go in the evenings, there could be a band with live music and dance.

491402063.name: Came here in daylight
491402063.author: a TripAdvisor user
491402063.reviewBody: Came for a quick look though the day. Had some nice food and cheap cold beers. Food was good. Lots of cheap stalls to buy souveneers if you want. Looked like it would be a pretty fun place after dark but didn\'t have time to stick around.

488056751.name: So glad to be back in the United States..
488056751.author: a TripAdvisor user
488056751.reviewBody:
My significant other and I took a bus tour across the border for the afternoon. The driver already knew the restaurant we were being taken to, and we landed there first for lunch. The restaurant was okay, good food. Drank coffee. Then, the traveling Mariachi band passed by and performed just outside the doorway....funneling all the music into the restaurant...which was so loud we could no longer have any discussions until they were done. It's as if they decided to play so loud that you were forced to pay them to leave you alone... Not a bad gig, I suppose. Oh well.

We walked up and down Revolution Avenue for a couple of hours. Basically, it was shop after shop selling cheap stuff I didn't need, and merchant after merchant trying to pull me into their shop selling cheap stuff I didn't need. I ended up buying a magnet and a poncho as souvenirs.... My honey bought a giant sombrero. Nice.

I was exhausted after that day, and I would never willingly choose to do that again. I saw enough..

487665450.name: Fun day walking around
487665450.author: a TripAdvisor user
487665450.reviewBody: Great shopping friendly people loved it going back today with all my family. More shopping for everyone.

486696221.name: The greatest place to go in Tijuana
486696221.author: a TripAdvisor user
486696221.reviewBody: This is the most historical place in Tijuana, it\'s worth to go there, I highly recommend it; you can find Mexican Curious, great Mexican Food and great places to relax with the family; you can find the origin of the famous Caesar\'s Salad.

484430994.name: Great place for a wander
484430994.author: a TripAdvisor user
484430994.reviewBody: This here for tourists mainly, plenty of shops, bars, food vendors, and of course pharmacy\'s. It is a lively place with lots going on, look out the the donkeys painted to look like zebras. Go here if you are looking for a bit of fun.

480692243.name: Fast paced & Vibrant
480692243.author: a TripAdvisor user
480692243.reviewBody: Love the energy of this city and its people. Everyone is friendly and very helpful and its a great road to find everything you need from shopping to getting your hair and nails done at a very reasonable cost, not to mention the delicious food.

480283721.name: Fun place to walk around and see downtown
480283721.author: a TripAdvisor user
480283721.reviewBody: Try to do that during the day not at night after sunset is not that great. It is better to take it over there is no parking so make sure you are aware of this.

478248467.name: Funny place with lot\'s of restaurants, bars and shops
478248467.author: a TripAdvisor user
478248467.reviewBody: It\'s fun to walk around and have a drink or food. Too much shop keepers trying to get you to their shop and maybe bit pricey compared to other places around. Cheap compared to USA

474703680.name: Mexican New Orleans......
474703680.author: a TripAdvisor user
474703680.reviewBody: Mexican New Orleans...... Do I need to say more ? Bars, unusual smells, occasional beggar, occasional prostitute, good food, drugs, & gift stores that all sell the same items (these require some price negotiations). If you don\'t like cerveza, tacos, and key chains; you may want to skip out. You can use dollars and pesos. Most people speak English or some form of Spanglish. Area appears to be safe (plenty of police on patrol).

473673709.name: Awesome for people watching and shopping
473673709.author: a TripAdvisor user
473673709.reviewBody: Definitely worth a visit - lots of shops, restaurants, art and murals. great place for an afternoon walk.

473481013.name: Lots of Drug Stores
473481013.author: a TripAdvisor user
473481013.reviewBody: My husband and I had four days in San Diego after a 15 day Panama Canal Cruise.  So we thought we would go to Tijuana for the morning and after lunch return to San Diego.  We did some looking around the area,  made two small purchases and had lunch before going to the Cultural Center.  Revolution street is a great street for looking for Mexican Souvenirs and purchasing your over priced prescriptions.  There are probably 10 Pharmacies in every block.  My husband is 70 and I\'m 64 and we are fortunate in that we don\'t have to take any meds.  But my suggestion is to get away from this area and see the more modern Tijuana.

473113541.name: Day Visit to Tijuana from San Diego. Nice leisurely visit to Avenida Revolucion
473113541.author: a TripAdvisor user
473113541.reviewBody: I went to Tijuana from San Diego on a day visit at the end of March, 2017. I had my evening meal at the La Casa Del Mole poblano, then returned to the Avenida Revolucion which seems to be the main street to while a way about 2 hours before my scheduled 9 pm return to the border. I spent a chunk of that time at the Praga Cafe (close to the junction of the 5th Avenue or Emiliano Zapata) drinking great coffee and watching TV but I spent about an hour strolling down the avenue. The Praga Cafe has a very lovely ambiance and very inviting modern decor. The menu look like it had some interesting stuff but I had already eating. What I saw people eating looked interesting though. The staff were young and spoke very good English. \nThis avenue comes alive at night! The mariachis came out in full force serenading people. Lots of people were strolling and chatting loudly and seem to be having a lot of fun. There was a relaxed vibe about the whole place. The shops which seem to sell all sorts of things remained open till late. I did not buy anything as I really don\'t do the touristy stuff much. There were lots of cafe which were full of people but an interesting place in the same block as the famous Caesar Hotel is called "Quiky\'s taco and fish" a large 2 story glass fronted corner space at the junction of Calle Salvador Diaz Miron (4th Avenue). The glass doors were flung open and it was full of people (couples?) dancing to salsa music. It was enchanting. I have no idea if it is always like that or it\'s a special occasion for those folks. They seem to be having a ball. I actually didn\'t see anyone eating. Maybe a few folks had drinks. I stood watching for a while with other locals. I did wander beyond the arch down the hill to the less savoury part of town around Avenida Constitucion and Calle Benito Juarez. It was full of scantily clad girls looking for "business". I found the place very uncomfortable and made a hasty retreat. I mean they were everywhere around that place and the city seem to have degenerated somewhat around that area. Beware! the police had a strong presence in town but thankfully I had no contact with them. I actually chattered my own taxi driver/guide for the 4-5 hours that I spent there. He waited for me while I did my thing although he went away when I was inside places we always set a time for him to return. That was my experience in a nutshell.

472941206.name: Not worth the visit if you ain\'t drinking!
472941206.author: a TripAdvisor user
472941206.reviewBody: Run down, tourist trap with aggressive vendors and it really smelled bad. I can check it off my list as a place I have been and a place I never plan to return too. Keep going further south in Mexico.

472654188.name: Run down
472654188.author: a TripAdvisor user
472654188.reviewBody:
Visited Revolution St. after having been gone for seven or so years. Not much has changed other than a remarkable reduction in strip clubs, a definite good thing! Unfortunately, those locations are now just boarded up storefronts. The same hustlers are hawking the same goods and they all have the same stuff.  One even whispered to me "we all have the same junk, mine is just cheaper". Yea, ok.

If it's your first time in TJ, make the trip. It's interesting. But stand your ground because everyone wants you to stop in their "shop" and see their great prices. They claim to have a lot of "hand made" products but the fact that you see so many duplicates at other stores should inform your opinion on their sourcing.

Many restaurants to choose from, most of Mexican cuisine, some from America like Dominos Pizza and Burger King.

Even a few night clubs to get your dance on.

Enjoy.

471363443.name: Always a San Diego Attraction
471363443.author: a TripAdvisor user
471363443.reviewBody: When I visit San Diego, I tend to spend more time south of the border. Because of my strict vegetarian diet, I avoid Mexican restaurants, unless they\'re in the U.S. (will have a better understanding). I walk the Avenida to browse the different shops, and admire the arch. I also socialize with the locals in Tijuana. I always have a great time shopping, browsing, or just admiring the city of Tijuana, MX. The burros, painted to resemble zebras, are a fun sight.

471087722.name: Very touristy area.
471087722.author: a TripAdvisor user
471087722.reviewBody: Lined with restaurants, bars and people selling all sorts of things. If you feel like getting out and walking around a bit, grabbing a bite to eat or buying souvenirs, visit here.

467703735.name: Fun in the sun\u2026\u2026.Summer is on its way, Good times ahead\u2026\u2026 go with your mind made up to have fun and you will\u2026..
467703735.author: a TripAdvisor user
467703735.reviewBody: $5 buck cab ride ..walk across from the US SIDE\u2026..Have fun enjoy TJ\u2026after sunset going down the hill under the arch and enjoy the Adult Zone\u2026\u2026.head to the Hotel! wake up fresh\u2026..taco Stand the next day.. then $5 buck cab back to the Border\u2026\u2026Great time!!

467149219.name: Shopping on Avenuda Revolucion...
467149219.author: a TripAdvisor user
467149219.reviewBody: Great leather products are made locally- jackets, purses, back packs, hats and much more.  There are also lots of shops selling Mexican hammocks, blankets, clothing, t-shirts, fireworks, pottery, jewelry and other typical tourist chochkes.  The shops close at 6 pm.  Fun exploring for treasures, and cheap prices for nice things, especially their leather goods.

467045142.name: Worse than 35 Years Ago
467045142.author: a TripAdvisor user
467045142.reviewBody: We drove to the border, parked in one of the lots nearby and walked into Mexico with our friends visiting from Spain.  We took a cab for $5 to Avenida Revolucion.  The street has no charm unless you count the burros painted like zebras on every corner as charming.  I had not been to Tijuana for 35 years and it was a big disappointment.  Now I never have to go again and my friends say they don\'t either.

466655008.name: Safest in the Day, Interesting at Night
466655008.author: a TripAdvisor user
466655008.reviewBody: One of Tijuana\'s most popular attractions - restaurants, bars, taco stands, nightclubs, clothing stores - you\'ll get a real feel for the original border town...

466400003.name: Interesting
466400003.author: a TripAdvisor user
466400003.reviewBody: Interesting strip of shops and restaurants.  Mostly tourist traps with the same things but we ended up in a couple of good shops.  If you are in the area this is a fun way to spend a couple of hours.

463854766.name: A great surprise
463854766.author: a TripAdvisor user
463854766.reviewBody: You basicly can find anything from great tacos, Carls Jr., souvenier shops and then great places that are popping up all over this street. Praga Caf\u00e9 is a great example, they have a fabulous menu for lunch, delicious sandwiches, coffee, desserts and at night they have concerts. Across the street you have Cesar\u00b4s Restaurant which re-opened around 2-3 years ago, this is the actual place where the world famous Cesar salad WAS INVENTED, it doesn\'t get any better, their entire menu is incredible, fabulous wines, desserts and they even have a small side area for tapas. On the 5th floor of a building between Revoluci\u00f3n and Constituci\u00f3n avenues there is a local brewery that is making the most awesome beers, which is why Tijuana is now the national leader inwhat they call Cervezas Artesanales, the non-comercial factory made variety, a must try!

462999369.name: Different Mexico then what we are used to (Riv Maya)
462999369.author: a TripAdvisor user
462999369.reviewBody: We wanted to do the border crossing on foot, and did which was cool, and did the walk from the border to Avenida.  We were surprised how undeveloped the walk was from the border to the Ave.  Once we got there, we were surprised that it was only 3 or 4 streets and not very long, not many shopping options or things to do.  We ended up grabbing lunch, doing a little shopping and heading back to the San Diego area--not staying nearly as long as we anticipated

460163177.name: Day trip in Revolucion
460163177.author: a TripAdvisor user
460163177.reviewBody:
This is the closest place from San Diego to have a taste of Mexico.
At day-time, good for shoppers of souvenirs. Just be careful in price negotiation. They always give you higher price to start, but you can bargain.
At nightime, this street turns into a big party place. you can go anywhere. dollars and mexican pesos are accepted.
Lot's of varieties for food and drinks. 
Police are visible but please be cautious all the time.
People are friendly and most speaks english.

457745358.name: Fun Place, lots of pushy shop owners
457745358.author: a TripAdvisor user
457745358.reviewBody: We spent an afternoon in the middle of January in old Tijuana, Revolucion street.   Lots of shops selling trinkets and food.  You can virtualy buy anything there, \n We found a little restaraunt just off Revolution that served up some excellent food and drinks at a great price.  If you can put up with the hustlers trying to drag you into thier stores, you will find some geat deals, and food at a great price.

457660663.name: Shop eat repeat
457660663.author: a TripAdvisor user
457660663.reviewBody: This street is good for a stroll and a few margaritas. I have no cell phone so the internet cafes were a godsend. Some Mexican style dollar stores kept the purchase of toiletries reasonable. Try the buffet at Sanborns for great value for your peso. Go off the beaten path to Zona Norte for even cheaper shopping and eats. Start at 2nd avenue and revolucion and walk to the US border - their is a hidden market - huge selection of trinkets, glass and iron works with incredible selection and pricing - some unique stuff to look at. Day or night it was an awesome first time (overnight) visit.

457187616.name: Feel Old and New Tijuana on One Street
457187616.author: a TripAdvisor user
457187616.reviewBody: From Caesar\'s Restaurat where the first caesar salad was created and can still be enjoyed, to a bar where you can sip tequila that has been marinated in a vat that contains a rattlesnake, to local banda musicians playing to historical buildings and everyday shops, you\'ll find it all on these blocks in downtown Tijuana.

456259290.name: steps away from hotel aqua rio
456259290.author: a TripAdvisor user
456259290.reviewBody: We had a drink at a club name copeo. Fun go there!!Hotel Aqua rio is very close to this famous street. We had ice cream at 42 flavors!

455104128.name: Warning for Tourists
455104128.author: a TripAdvisor user
455104128.reviewBody:
Revolution is a great place to go party and enjoy yourselves, it is really fun on the weekends and since the Mexican peso has dropped in value you can get a lot for so little. The nightclubs are amazing and way better than most San Diego nightclubs and bars. 

BUT BE ADVISED, The city's police force is STILL out of control and very corrupt regardless of what you hear in the news that it's "gotten better". I strongly advise that you to utilize taxis, Uber or public transit at night. There are so many, SO MANY municipal (city) police officers circling around the Centro area at night, especially around Revolution Ave looking for Americans to pull over and hassle some money or to steal some valuables from their cars.

It has NOT gotten any better, over the past 8 years I've been going down there and Ive seen how it has gotten worse and these officers have become more ruthless. For this reason I have not gone there as much as before, because I had my money and my ring stolen from these officers. 

You know they're up to no good when they approach you without any visible name tags or they usually place their walkie-talkie in front of their name tag so you won't know who they are. 

Tijuana offers an "anonymous" tip line to report such officers, trust me,   just like their city police, its 100% useless. 

This applies to Mexican-Americans too. It does not matter if you speak Spanish. Even my Mexican relatives from Mexico City had become victims of Tijuanas corrupt police force. Although Mexico is generally not a third world country, some major cities  like Tijuana are. 

Anyways,
6th Ave has a great selection of bars. My favorite places to eat are the tacos along the boardwalk by Hotel Nelson.

454117317.name: GREAT FOOD ALONG THE AVENUE.
454117317.author: a TripAdvisor user
454117317.reviewBody: This street in the busy city of "TJ" has a wide variety of Restaurants. An excellent place to start is Caesar Restaurant where the authentic Caesar Salad was invented. \n10 blocks of great restaurants and "Curios" Shops. Dance Clubs and more.

453153858.name: Scary place
453153858.author: a TripAdvisor user
453153858.reviewBody: I did not enjoy my day trip to Tijuana. Went with a friend from San Diego, he refused to drive there because many drivers are uninsured and the queue to return across the border is horrendous. The area is swamped by beggars, children pulling at your trousers constantly trying to sell their junk. There are groups of armed Police all over the place and frankly I felt unsafe. We were told not to eat or drink anything that does not come out of a sealed pack or bottle. Constantly harassed by shopkeepers and I was pleased to leave.

451351926.name: TJ downtown trip
451351926.author: a TripAdvisor user
451351926.reviewBody:
Went to walk the downtown in TJ
And I saw a lot of security (police man)
But driving is a mess
Almost impossible
And bottlenecks
Like souveniers prices
But also a red zone
Seems dangerous at night

445958668.name: Kind of junky
445958668.author: a TripAdvisor user
445958668.reviewBody: A number of small shops and restaurants. Much of these items are actually made in China. \n\nNothing special even though the local government keeps spend money on redevelopment. It\'s a border street, so it classically bumpy and junky. But if in the area it\'s an ok visit. Otherwise save your time and money.

445684447.name: Symbol of change
445684447.author: a TripAdvisor user
445684447.reviewBody: If you do not know where the Avenue is, just ask (preferably) the police how to get to the arch of center of the city, that is where it is. Walking from the from the boarder cross the river, it will be about 20 minutes.  The Avenue is the heart of the City with many shops, restaurants, markets and lots of pharmacies. Many of the old buildings are in the area.  Day time, it is very lively with tourists (Americans and Mexicans) and some cultural performance on the state at the Artisan market. Go and experience yourself with food and drinks. Buy some trinkets if you are that type of tourist.  I was a little disappointed not seeing any zebra donkeys at all. Hopefully the city will revive to the good old days stage in a few years.

445489345.name: A new vibe for an old street
445489345.author: a TripAdvisor user
445489345.reviewBody: Visit it, walk it, and dinne in it... This is a new revolution street. The effort is growing to change the old vibe and now show the new tijuana

443190924.name: Mexico, yes, Mexico!!!
443190924.author: a TripAdvisor user
443190924.reviewBody: I thoroughly enjoy experiencing different people and different cultures.  Buildings are old, yes.  Adds to the character.  Streets are clean.  I don\u00b4t enjoy being amongst a bunch of tourists and this area did not disappoint.

442962944.name: Cool
442962944.author: a TripAdvisor user
442962944.reviewBody: Never been before and lots of people tried to dissuade us from crossing the border and glad we didn\'t listen to them. Crossing back and forth was painless in the middle of a weekday and best of all Uber works in Tijuana so transportation in Mexico was easy. The Avenida was fun and adventurous and was a well enjoyed activity. Not sure what it\'s like at night but during the day it was very friendly and non threatening.

440475567.name: Trying harder
440475567.author: a TripAdvisor user
440475567.reviewBody:
I had not been to Tijuana for a number of years. Let's be honest. I visited TJ for the same reason as many Americans. There are those of us who want to claim foreign travel, but cannot afford the week long fancy cruises, airline tickets, hotel stays or other costs of foreign travel. TJ has little to do with the rich varied Mexican culture and history. The main tourist street has for a long time been a collection of small shops filled with Asian-made clothing and trinkets, tawdry bars, and pharmacies often offering drugs and services not available in the US. There were exceptions, a few quality drinking establishments and restaurants and a few US-based fast food chains. Actuary many males went for the places offering cheap sex. Then the drug wars ramped up and many Americans were scared off, helped by warnings from the US State Department. 

Things have changed. First, there is massive construction on both sides of the border station. The American building that stretched the width of the roadway is gone. Check the Internet for updates. In the meantime, entering Mexico is now done on the east side. It used to be just walk through a turnstile and go on your way. Now, you stop and show ID and fill out a former. I also saw soldiers, armed with rifles. Obviously, Mex6has ramped up its own security. It also puts you on the wrong side of the highway for crossing the bridge to downtown. Recommendation: take a taxi or use a shuttle from the US side.

Avenue Revoluccion, the main tourist area is changing. TJ is obviously attempting a major upgrade to attract Norteamericanos and dollars. New construction is going up. Most of the old tawdry bars are gone. There is a transportation station going up in the middle of the street. Planters are being added to make it look more like a Boulevard. The jail Lai front on is still there. The fast food places are still there. But there are more nice bars and eating places. Some of the old stores are still there trading in jewelry and clothing. It won't ever remind people of Rodeo Drive.  But it's a large change for TJ.

Yes, for those interested, the tawdry bars are still available, or so I was told. You just won't find them on Avenue Revoluccion. I am also not covering other areas or sights available in Tijuana as I am not much familiar with them. Others can fill in the holes or just use the Internet. Once again, I recommend a taxi back to the border. The route and traffic can make it a hassle but I have never been cheated by a TJ cabbie. The US station has also switched sides at least temporarily. Adding technology has speeded things up somewhat and the US has a special card available to FastTrack things. Check the border patrol Web site for details.

One last item. I have not discussed driving over the border. I have never done it. Frankly, I have been scared off by horror stories dealing with Mexican insurance (absolutely recommended) and witnessing TJ traffic. I have also seen miles of lines trying to enter the US. There is probably better info available from others that have actually done it.

437853567.name: Touristy
437853567.author: a TripAdvisor user
437853567.reviewBody: We went on a Monday. There was no line to get back over to the United States, but also at least half the shops on Revolucion were closed. There was music and several restaurants, some hotels, and places to buy souvenirs.  The tacos we got on Avenida Revolucion were mediocre. Our taxi driver did tell us that just about anywhere off the main tourist drag had better tacos. Hotel Nelson did had a good coffee stand and a friendly staff when we asked about the local sites. \n\nWe actually liked the "Mercado artesania" better than Revolucion. The artisanal market is right by the walkway back to the United States, so it\'s a good last place to stop. People were actually making crafts while we were there. They were making leather purses, painting plates, and making jewelry.

436869456.name: Good outing
436869456.author: a TripAdvisor user
436869456.reviewBody: The main reason is to see the shops and restaurants. Very safe area and lots to see and do. Highly recommend

435930194.name: lovly mexican walk
435930194.author: a TripAdvisor user
435930194.reviewBody: walk 20 minutes, and enjoy the mexican curios, you always can make a pitstop at Cesars restaurante or any other bar, arounda the streets

435737123.name: Lively athmosphere...
435737123.author: a TripAdvisor user
435737123.reviewBody: The arch is seen from all around and thus you cannot get lost. There is music all over the area around the arch. The Avenida Revolucion has all kinds of shops and restaurants. Just to walk on it is a nice experience in itself. Make sure you bargain, when you buy something.

435675359.name: Fun strip
435675359.author: a TripAdvisor user
435675359.reviewBody: During the day you can find all kinds of traditional souvenirs as well as good restaurants. At night they have all kinds of bars, cantinas, karaoke bars, you name it. Fun for all!

434274432.name: Open air market
434274432.author: a TripAdvisor user
434274432.reviewBody: A nice place to get souvenirs. Of course don\'t pay their asking price. You can at least get half of what they are asking.  Be careful  going off the Main Street. It can get very seedy, very fast. We felt safe on the Main Street . Not so much on the side streets. By nice place to see.

434120618.name: Fun For drinkers and gamblers
434120618.author: a TripAdvisor user
434120618.reviewBody: It\'s a cool strip. The casino is really fun for table games and the bars are pumping all night.\n\nWorth staying on the strip.

433675760.name: Interesting
433675760.author: a TripAdvisor user
433675760.reviewBody: After crossing the border into Mexico, Avenida Revoluccion is just a 10 walk from there. It\'s full of restaurants that have waiters outside that try to get you to enter their place and other souvenir shops. The food was ok (I only ate at one place). However, if you wander on, you will see a working class section of Tijuana where people are on their way to school, work, church and other various places. We also made a turn into Tijuana\'s red-light district. Tons of women outside though I did not get offered drugs of any sort.

433399179.name: Smelly dirty and shady
433399179.author: a TripAdvisor user
433399179.reviewBody: We landed in Tijuana before going back to San Francisco, from  Cancun what a difference  Tijuana  has great food way better but the city is so run down the revo is your best bet if it\'s your first time shops restaurant  are all in one location short walk from the boarder  no were as clean and modern  like Cancun.. \nStop by enjoy the food take a picture with Monica the donkey  zebra.

431053525.name: Disappointed
431053525.author: a TripAdvisor user
431053525.reviewBody: Expected more. Dirty and most shops all had the same thing. People were friendly but not worth the time spent waiting in line to come back across border.

429826368.name: Avenue with lots of touristics options to spend an evening
429826368.author: a TripAdvisor user
429826368.reviewBody: Along the street you can find lots of places for getting a drink or buying some souvenirs, sadly though it is very touristically focused and you wont find nothing very cultural nor surprising

428961805.name: Interesting place to visit and shopping
428961805.author: a TripAdvisor user
428961805.reviewBody: Revolution ave is an interesting place to shop/eat. When shopping souvenirs, be ready to bargain. We recently visited this place and one of my friends liked something which was around $65 USD, we started negotiating and by the time, we were out of the shop, the guy was asking for $30 USD. Make sure to check how the situation is in TJ because of recent drug cartel activities. We were told that it affected the tourism more than 50%.

425655814.name: Visit the San Diego International Fringe
425655814.author: a TripAdvisor user
425655814.reviewBody: Bi-National portion of the Fringe is in Pasae Rodriguez during the Fringe.  Two Great venues between Revolution and Constitution.  The entire Pasae is full of artisans and has coffee shops, bars, and restaurants along with all the vendors and restaurants on Revolution.  Great short (60 minutes of less) plays in English, Spanish or maybe even Italian????\n

422931977.name: Very affordable
422931977.author: a TripAdvisor user
422931977.reviewBody: It\'s a nice place to visit, but you have to be aware that\'s it is a tourist trap and people will hassle you to sell you their souvenirs and stuff. Bargaining is the thing to do here and you can get anything very cheap. What i liked most is that eating and drinking in bars/restaurants is very cheap as well.

420005061.name: Interesting and fun for tourists
420005061.author: a TripAdvisor user
420005061.reviewBody:
We went to TJ for the day to see this area and experience Mexico.  I had been through there on a bus going to San Diego from Ensanada in the early 2000s but we didn't stop and I would have been scared because it looked unsafe.  This time we wanted to go get souveniers and see the area close to the border but in a safer area of TJ.  We decided to take a bus in as the walkway is a very long and busy area.  The bus line near Ross and the shopping center was a good cheaper choice.  They took us through customs.  3 of our 4 didn't have a passport but we were just told to have one next time.  They scanned the bus and our personal belongings then we went on.  The bus had stopped at several places and picked up others so don't be alarmed.  They dropped some passengers off at various locations then took us to a store where we got into a van that continued on to the Revolucion area.  They dropped us off at a store selling liquor where we got free tequilla shots.  They also introduced us to a cab driver Tito, who would take the 4 of us back to the border for $6 total. 

The area is designed for tourists as there are shops galore along with many places to eat and drink.  Many of the stores sell the same things so we didn't buy at 1st but wanted to walk and experience the area.  There are neat pieces of art work there and we saw several police officers so we felt safe.  One officer let us goof off and one leaned up on his car like she was being arrested while we took a pic.  He was very nice and funny.  

Shopping:  be prepared for aggressive shop people.  They will try to sell you multiple things and try to get you to come in their store.  They will bargain and haggle so don't accept the price until you barter.  We found most would come down half price from their original price!  Street vendorswill come up and try to sell you silver and other items they carry but beware, we were told by the cop to watch as their quality is questionable with some of them.  Be prepared for children to come up and try to sell you trinkets too! We did buy from one street vendor, the man set up making name bracelets and necklaces or pins from wire.  He makes them right there in front of you and were very neat!  He has set prices and does not bargain but was very worth it as they were $5 and $9 I believe so not expensive for hand made items.  We did tip him as we loved how great the work was! 

We did not eat while there but did buy bottle drinks at a store as it was hot.  We didn't go off the main street and walked to the arch and back then were hot and tired so we decided to let Tito take us back.  His cab was blue and white.  Don't be too scared of drivers in Mexico.  They are aggressive and blow their horns at each other and will put their car in an inch of space to get in a lane.  At one time we were 4 wide in what was supposed to be 2 lanes.  Lol  but we made it to the border and he took us right to the walkway to get through customs.  Customs was very busy and there were several lanes of people walking across so people with documents or passports got through faster than those of us with just drivers licenses.  We just gave our license, the customs officer punched it in and we were walking back into the USA.  

It was a great experience to see a different side of Tijuana than the dirty scary area we drove through years ago.  We felt very safe but wouldn't venture there at night or alone.  My cousin lives in Mexico and told us to make sure we were out of there by dark as it is a different area when the sun goes down and you end up somewhere you shouldn't be.

419585239.name: Fun time!
419585239.author: a TripAdvisor user
419585239.reviewBody: I traveled to Tijuana\'s Avenida Revolucion with 3 friends on a Saturday afternoon and had a great time. Our main goals were to get a little taste of Mexico while eating and drinking for cheap. Mission Accomplished! We took a quick 5 minute taxi ride from the border to Avenida Revolucion and when we arrived we were greeted with live music, street performers dancing traditional Mexican dances, rows of people selling souvenirs, and a galore of restaurants ready to feed us. Keep in mind, however, that this is a very touristy area so the prices for food and drinks in this area are what you would likely pay (or slightly less than you would pay) in the States. We ate some tacos, which were okay, and had some drinks at a restaurant in the area and enjoyed the atmosphere. It was a great time. \n\nHowever, if you are looking for cheap drinks and food, venture out of the main Avenida Revolucion and keep walking down the street to find ridiculously cheap drinks, amazing tacos and seafood, and some fun dancing spots. These places are a lot less crowded but have way better deals.

418695647.name: Main square in Tijuana
418695647.author: a TripAdvisor user
418695647.reviewBody: I\'d say it\'d be pretty difficult to visit Tijuana without stumbling upon this square--this area is filled with great restaurants and touristy shops. A great landmark to the city.

416171901.name: yup - revolucion - the good, the bad, the ugly
416171901.author: a TripAdvisor user
416171901.reviewBody: I passed through here with the wife - the good is that you are in Mexico and there is good food - the bad is that its totally commercial "gringo land" and its very tourist oriented, particularly towards 21 year olds that want to get drunk - but there are some good items in the gift shops, and its a fun way to spend the afternoon.  Many of the bars have the music up way to loud

412530351.name: The TJ arch
412530351.author: a TripAdvisor user
412530351.reviewBody: I love to travel here. Leave wallet and cell phone home and don\'t put cash all in one pocket. It will get picked, maybe not your first visit here but maybe 50 50 chance. Plenty of police around so feels very safe from violence. But the police have try to steal from me as well. Again, leave value stuff at home and it will be an awesome visit.

412071776.name: Night out
412071776.author: a TripAdvisor user
412071776.reviewBody: We whent to las pulgas night club on Revolucion Blvd, it was a great night we had a lot of fun with friends and family members I love TJ when you\'re bored take a trip down there it\'s extremely affordable.\nWell I hope this review is helpful and another thing there is a lot of people at Las pulgas so you need to get there early to get a table.

410287531.name: Crazy Teenagers Party Days
410287531.author: a TripAdvisor user
410287531.reviewBody: Back in late 80\'s this place was the party place in Mexico for US Military and US College kids... crazy FUN - 9 blocks of bars, clubs and some restaurants.... Now is quiet not the same - you still have some places were you can go and have some drinks but is not the crazy place like it use to be...

401085864.name: Walking wallet, much?
401085864.author: a TripAdvisor user
401085864.reviewBody:
This was our first time visiting Tijuana. We took the blueline trolley (really a light rail) down to San Ysidro from San Diego for a daytrip. The trolley/light rail was efficient but a little overpriced ($7 per person round trip). You have to walk past the McDonald's at the San Ysidro station if you take the trolley down in order to access the border; don't turn around and go to the bridge/walkway. That was a bit misleading and there weren't a lot of signs to guide you. 

It was unclear how far Tijuana was from the border. We didn't realize that Tijuana was a 2 &1/2 mile walk from the border, and considering the heat, we ended up taking a taxi. The taxi driver was extremely helpful and friendly; he was probably the best part of our trip! 

Once we arrived at the arc, we were instantly flagged down by many shopkeepers who were rather aggressive in trying to reel in customers. I lost track of how many times I had to say, "no thank you." I really felt like a walking wallet or perhaps a walking red flag. I'd much prefer to approach a shopkeeper if I want help rather than have him/her approach me before I even enter a store. This aggressive approach does not seem to be the most effective marketing strategy, as shoppers seem to end up feeling more annoyed than interested. 

There was at least one nice clothing store where the prices were set and the shopkeepers weren't aggressive but that seemed to be the exception rather than the norm. I also don't understand the hype around taking one's picture with the "zonkeys." Those poor animals must be sweltering in the heat. 

I'd recommend going to Tijuana only for the experience of travelling to a different country and because it is good to get out of your comfort zone sometimes. Maybe there's something I just didn't "get" about Avenida Revolucion because it was my first time. It was an experience, I guess, but certainly not the highlight of visiting the San Diego area.

400448717.name: Day excursion to Tijuana
400448717.author: a TripAdvisor user
400448717.reviewBody: My family and I visited San Diego. We really wanted to visit Tijuana. We started off by taking the Red Trolley (really a light rail) on the Blue Line. The Blue Line took us right to the border at San Ysidro. There was a money exchange place. It was confusing which direction to go. We saw a large Mexican flag, so we headed in that direction, walking on a large walkway. When we got off, we had no idea where we were. We saw border guards and asked them. They told us to go back the way we came and to behind the McDonalds (by the last trolley stop). Behind the McDonalds, we followed a narrow lane to the border check, where our passports were stamped. As we emerged from there, we were confused where to go. There were loads of taxis (we were under the impression we could walk to the Avenida Revolucion--we could not. A very nice taxi driver spoke in English and gave us very good tips. He dropped us off at 1st and Revolucion. He advised us not to venture beyond 6th Street, because beyond that, the area is not patrolled. We noted a police car parked on the street. The taxi cab driver also advised us to wait by a pharmacy on the corner of 2nd St. when we needed a taxi to return. My family and I immediately felt like "tourists with a red flag". We really stood out. Most merchants accept American dollars, but some only accept pesos--so it is a good idea to exchange money in San Ysidro (border--close to McDonalds). I exchanged a $20.00 for pesos. Not knowing the exchange rate, my pesos were gone by the first vendor.. Exchagning $40.00 is probably a better idea. I know I was "taken" by the first vendor on the right. There were three men, so with all talking to me at once, I was confused. I purchased a hat and a sugar skull. They kept trying to talk me into buying other things. One of the men said, "Package deal." (this refers to items added on - who knows if one really gets a discount. One of the men said (regarding pesos) "Two and then one for me--beer", As we walked, there were men along the street trying to sell things--very aggressive. Three little girls approached my daughter. She gave the one girl $5.00, but the girl still stood by my daughter (I guess looking for more--my daughter speaks and understands Spanish pretty well, but she was unable to determine what the little girl was saying or wanted), holding her little tray of small toys and gum. I felt so bad for the girls, but we had to move on. In one of the street vendor\'s store, (around 4th or 5th St) where a woman, Rosita, greeted me. She was very kind, and I was not "taken". There I purchased two belts and a charm for a necklace. She had real silver charms. On the corner of 4th St. on the right (may have been 3rd), there was a nice store-a real store with set prices. I purchased a nice pair of sneakers for $20 and two soccer shirts. We walked to 6th Street, turned around, and walked up the other side of Revolucion (now facing the arch). I stopped in a vendor with a few leather goods (my family was anxious to get back, so they waited for me). I finally saw leather hats I had seen in pictures. Unfortunately, the hat did look good on me, so I did not buy it. We walked to the pharmacy (same side) and caught another cab. The driver was quiet (I don\'t think he spoke English), however, he did an awesome job navigating through very heavy traffic and through a large chaotic circle (I thought only NJ had those!). Then we walked back to the border check. That whole area was cement, wire, and grafitti--very poor and very urban. There was a very very long line to get back into the US. Eventually we were called and our passports and purchases were checked. It was a relief to get back onto the Red Trolley--which was waiting by the McDonalds. My daughter said she felt like a "walking wallet" the entire time. I agreed. It is very hot, so take a hat with you--don\'t buy it in Tijuana. Head left by the McDonalds when you get off the trolley--not right, where the walkway and Mexico flag are. There are tons of border patrol agents, so do not be surprised. Have your passports out. Expect  the area to the taxis to look very urban and poor. Take a taxi by all means. We were under the impression we could walk to Avendido Revolucion. It would have been a very long and hot walk with tons of traffic and no place to walk on the street. I had read where Avienda Revolucion is one of the great shopping places (it is not what I expected). When we asked a border patrol officer how to get there, he had no idea what we were talking about. The taxi drivers were awesome--especially the first. The cab fare was $8.00. We gave  him a $10.00. Know that there was no food, some small vendors close to the taxis. We did not buy any. Please do not take a large purse/pocketbook. Use sunscreen. Bring a large bottle of water with you. Expect to be hot. Also, families--do not be surprised at how many sex/porn places there are as well as pharmacies selling Viagra and Cialis. The day was interesting, but we could not wait to get back to the US.

400148356.name: This is the place to go for souvenirs in TJ
400148356.author: a TripAdvisor user
400148356.reviewBody: Revolucion street is where everyone goes for souvenirs. Also, the famous Caesar\'s hotel and restaurant where the original Caesar\'s salad was invented is on Revolucion street. There are many street vendors, fruit vendors, leather goods, trinkets, photo opportunities with the burro "zebras" as well as regular stores. It\'s a long street with many interesting sights.

398877639.name: Enjoy but be careful!!!o in groups
398877639.author: a TripAdvisor user
398877639.reviewBody: I live in Playas ... the beach for Tijuana.. this area is a high traffic area for tourists but is well worth the effort to get there ... Full of local shops, bars, peddlers, and tourist stuff.   ALSO... be ware of the ripoff artist... leave nothing on your tables at lunch, do not wear you watches, and leave your cell phone hanging.. be aware of your surroundings at all times and you will have a blast!!! .. Laddies, i suggest you go in groups or families etc .. but don\'t wander alone .. particularly north of 1st Ave..... At night this is not a place for the "go alone" person unless you up up for for adventure that may result in police, or hospital visits..., This is not to scare you... days time with company .. no problems.... Enjoy all the attractions and distractions and count your change!!!

394100051.name: Super fun !!!
394100051.author: a TripAdvisor user
394100051.reviewBody: Is the heart of Tijuana, super fun, full of life and interesting things to do, from taking your picture with a burro-cebra, from getting good food and crafts.

393089854.name: Fun
393089854.author: a TripAdvisor user
393089854.reviewBody: So much fun, so little time!!! :)  No need to convert your dollars to pesos, most places will take American money

392328229.name: Great shops
392328229.author: a TripAdvisor user
392328229.reviewBody: We walked down the Avenue and found some great jewels but you have to look for them.  Haggle the price and walk away if it doesn\'t suit you.  There are plenty of other shops that you probably will find something comparable and for the price you like.

389940900.name: For the first timers a nice place to experience another country, but a bit touristy
389940900.author: a TripAdvisor user
389940900.reviewBody: If you are in Mexico the first time, come here for something to see, to taste, to smell, and to shop. Beware that many shops cater to tourists, but it doesn\'t mean you can\'t get some nice bargains on curios. Stroll through the very safe street and take in the sights. Once you got the rhythm, then expand your exploration to the side streets and meet the locals.

389915615.name: TJ is coming back to life!
389915615.author: a TripAdvisor user
389915615.reviewBody: Went Avenida Revolucion last weekiend. TJ is coming back to life. Had a great time exploring many shops and restaurants.

389569514.name: You cannot avoid it when traveling to Tijuana downtown
389569514.author: a TripAdvisor user
389569514.reviewBody: Visited Tijuana in the morning from vacation in San Diego, walked from the border to the Tijuana Arch - about 20-30 minute walk.  From there walked up and down the Avendia for a little ways.  The street smelled from the nightlife before.  Different tourist shops and people trying to get you to buy something.  On some parts of the street, the is public art sculptures which was sort of nice and interesting.

388471623.name: Fun shopping
388471623.author: a TripAdvisor user
388471623.reviewBody: My teens loved shopping here and bargaining for their purchases.  Shopkeepers were somewhat agressive but never rude.  Friendly and helpful.

387554371.name: Very crowded, touristy
387554371.author: a TripAdvisor user
387554371.reviewBody: We visited on a weekend. Very crowded. Lots of trinkets to buy as souvenirs. If you love bargaining this place is for you. Lots of eateries. Didn\'t try them though. Need to watch out for vendors trying to entice you with their wares. There was traditional Mexican dancing on the street square which the kids enjoyed for a while. Near the arch of Tijuana where you could take pictures...

385670250.name: TJ Wedding
385670250.author: a TripAdvisor user
385670250.reviewBody: Was surprised TJ has some upscale hotels. I hadn\'t been there in years. still as busy but some areas are very different

385431949.name: Dull, tourist trap- changed from 25-30 yrs ago.  A Tuesday midday visit.
385431949.author: a TripAdvisor user
385431949.reviewBody:
We are a family of 5- husband, wife and 3 boys- 1 late teen and 2 early elementary.  We spent a week plus in San Diego and we parents had fond memories of visiting Avenida Revolution as early teens with our respective families.
The vibrancy that was once there is there no longer.  Now it is just a few shops of tchotchkes, pharmacies and OK restaurants. So many closed storefronts.  No street food vendors.  No crowds thronging with excitement. 2 tired zonkeys. Our taxi driver tried to discourage us from going there saying it is nothing like it once was and he was right.  Shop owners weren't interested in bartering.

We did walk down a cross street to the Cathedral which was pretty and the shops along the way were far more interesting.

We also walked to a local modern mall and the Cultural Center.  Sadly, we didn't have time to enjoy the Cultural Center, but wish we had.  Enjoyed our lunch in a café across from the mall and walked back to the border.

Don't go back expecting past versions.  It is quite dull now.

385412368.name: A must see in TJ, but only during the day (if you bring the family)
385412368.author: a TripAdvisor user
385412368.reviewBody: Revolucion is a must see attraction if you are with some friends or "significant other"...but only bring the kids in the morning.....it\'s not a place to be at night with kids, or alone. A lot of fun can be had there, but be careful and don\'t flash your money around or be getting too drunk and rowdy. You gotta stay alert, but it can still be a lot of fun.

384312765.name: Tijuana tourist hot spot
384312765.author: a TripAdvisor user
384312765.reviewBody: If you are a college student anywhere in the the Southwest/SoCal, you have likely come to party at Avenida Revolucion. There are bars, shops, and food lining this street and has been a popular tourist attraction for many years. It doesn\'t have the same hustle and bustle as it once did but it is still a fun place to go.\n\nAs fun as it is, you do have to be careful; you can get robbed, get in a fight, or make some other regrettable decisions here if you are not careful. Just be careful how much you drink and make sure you don\'t go off by yourself.

384117015.name: Great Fun Cleaned UP
384117015.author: a TripAdvisor user
384117015.reviewBody: Revolution Ave is great. I could not believe how they had cleaned it up.  The trash and shady characters were gone. Much better than a few years ago. I felt safe with a small police presence. We had 2 for $1 Al Pastor tacos, $1 beers Great. Haggling with the street vendors should not be missed.

384030471.name: Not the Revolucion of 20 yrs ago.
384030471.author: a TripAdvisor user
384030471.reviewBody: Ave Revolucion of 2016 is not the same as the Revolucion of 1996. Gone are the drunk gringos and sailors who were replaced by locals seeking a good night with live music. Almost every bar or club we went to had live music, and the sounds are uniquely Tijuana - a fusion of Norte\u00f1a music and english dance hits. The Ave could still be shady a bit and I would be watchful, but still this edginess is what makes this place unique.

383989387.name: Day trip from SD
383989387.author: a TripAdvisor user
383989387.reviewBody: I took the trolley from downtown to have a look at Tijuana. It was ok. I went on a Sunday so afew shops were closed, but there was some cool artwork on the pull down roller doors. Pretty touristy. Got some cheap tacos, wandered around and took photos then came back. A good way to spend a day but if you\'ve done it once, you wouldn\'t need to go back again.

377781293.name: Imagine Bourbon Street but with more breathing room and it smells better.
377781293.author: a TripAdvisor user
377781293.reviewBody: Definitely worth taking a trip to Revolution Avenue if only to sight see and people watch. Very touristy and full of shops, bars, restaurants, etc... The dollar is very strong right now so there are good deals to be had all up and down the Avenue.

377754225.name: A shadow of its former self
377754225.author: a TripAdvisor user
377754225.reviewBody: Avenida Revolucion has never fully recovered from its heyday before drug wars brought a multi-year hiatus to tourism. Still, it\u00b4s worth a visit. You can still have your picture taken on a zonkey to prove you really were in Tijuana. There are still some decent curio and artisan shops along the street and some wonderful artisan shops in some of the alleys. And you can still get the best and orginal Caesar\'s salad made at your table at Caesar\'s, a must for every visitor!

376370965.name: Not like the old days.
376370965.author: a TripAdvisor user
376370965.reviewBody: I have been coming to revolucion ave for 40 years, always loved seeing the shops, going down stairs to many more. so sad no more shopping here. No tourtist, only locals on the streets. a few shops open.

376269071.name: This used to be a nice place!
376269071.author: a TripAdvisor user
376269071.reviewBody: This is a tourist spot which is why I dislike. Too many people trying to sell you things, people asking for money and just don\'t feel safe walking here. If you like being where tourists go to then go but if not you will not miss anything because this does not show what Mexico is really about there is way much better and prettier things to see elsewhere. La Revo is what makes Mexico get all of its stereotypes from literally, so cliche!

374255386.name: As Tijuana moves up Revolucion goes down
374255386.author: a TripAdvisor user
374255386.reviewBody: Sad to see the deterioration of the businesses on Revolucion. Not much of interest there other than Cesar\'s. There are 2 or 3 nice shops (especially the one next door to Cesar\'s) but the rest had nothing to crow about. The shops down the allies were the most interesting. I was surprised none of the stores were selling Donald Trump pinatas. \n\nGo to the beaches. Visit the Cultural Center. Shop in the Artisan\'s Market (better selection and prices) and eat at Maiz. Skip the strip.

373250857.name: A remnant of what used to be
373250857.author: a TripAdvisor user
373250857.reviewBody: A different scene these days.  Gone are the days of tijuana being a party spot where all the college kids from states went to drink and party.  There are some clubs and sports bars still happening on the weekends but the masses of people are gone.  You hardly see any foreigners now which is not necessarily a bad thing but If you see any americans, its mostly Mexican americans that have family there.  There is still a nightlife scene on revolucion but now its more of a local one. Some places are just remnants if their former selves.  The drug cartel wars have really impacted the area.  Its is however a safe place these days but the tourism has not yet recovered.  The one thing that is still awesome is the street food!

373029304.name: Better Shopping Elsewhere!
373029304.author: a TripAdvisor user
373029304.reviewBody: The driver who brought us to the shopping plaza gave us 30 minutes to shop because our group was from the bariatric surgery center and we had to get back to the hotel. So he pulled up to this shop and said we could shop there. There were 6 in our group. So we go into this small shop and the guys in there would not let us shop and look around every thing we looked at  they asked "did we want it?" "And they would work with us on the price if we bought more than 1 item." One guy followed me all over the little shop asking me questions and getting real close to me while talking to me. This I did not like! And while you were walking down the street in front of other shops the guys would shout "hey lady come in I got what u looking for." And if u slowed down just to look outside they would come out and ask " what do u want? What ever it is just tell me an we work on price." That drove me crazy! The shop keepers were very pushy. We didn\'t get to shop long. I would have liked to shop more but we couldn\'t . The prices were very negotable. There wasn\'t a lot of people there but there was a large variety of different things at the shops. If you are a person who does not mind haggling with the shop keepers then this may be the place for you! I\'ve read where people didn\'t feel save while there but we felt safe no complaints there. In fact we saw police patrolling on foot and in cars. So I guess they are trying to get more tourist back into this area.

369602214.name: Dirty, Depressing - there are so many better places in Mexico
369602214.author: a TripAdvisor user
369602214.reviewBody: Tijuana is not the place to experience Mexico or Mexican culture.   Sadly Tijuana is so rundown.  The Mexican people are fine and helpful.  You may find a couple of places to eat that are good Mexican food, but many that are not.    You will be inundated with \'farmacias\' if you are looking for medicines without a prescription.

369540455.name: Nice Walk
369540455.author: a TripAdvisor user
369540455.reviewBody: nice walk not what it use to be before is not alive as before not enjoyable love to eat at different stands.

368686850.name: La Revo!!!
368686850.author: a TripAdvisor user
368686850.reviewBody: Full of color, bars and shops.  Excellent place to walk around and buy some stuff.  Parking will be difficult but there are several parking spaces with reasonable cost.

366387229.name: Have to do it once
366387229.author: a TripAdvisor user
366387229.reviewBody: Our first trip to Tijuana, and everyone said, well, you have to go to Revolucion Street, it\'s the tourist drag. Apparently it\'s been cleaned up, but it\'s still pretty depressing. Lots of tourist shops with proprietors standing outside trying to get you in. Personally, I hate that kind of hard sell. There are a few good restaurants on the street--Caesar\'s is famous and supposed to be very good. We did eventually find a little gift shop with a proprietor who was helpful and nice without being overly obtrusive. Glad we went, glad I don\'t have to go back!

366357898.name: Lots of Shopping Opportunities
366357898.author: a TripAdvisor user
366357898.reviewBody: It was fun to go to Avenida Revolucion.  I would have done more buying than shopping if the shopkeepers hadn\'t been so pushy.  I wish they understood that I was already there to purchase so their pushiness really only served to push me away.  That being said, many people enjoy the haggling process and for those that do this is an excellent place to engage in it.  So many wonderful artisanal items available to bring home!

365840261.name: getting old and lots of police
365840261.author: a TripAdvisor user
365840261.reviewBody: It used to be the place to go for drinks and dinner, now its a shell of the old Tijuna,most places empty or very few people, most people now go past TJ to get to the coast

365738547.name: Super Rude Shop Keepers \ud83d\ude08
365738547.author: a TripAdvisor user
365738547.reviewBody:
I was there Friday Apr 15th 2016.

I was there with my mom and dad looking for souvenirs for my kids.

Super Rude shop keepers. 

I have been around the world from Japan to New Zealand and plenty of places in between.☺ I have been to many, many souvenir shopping expeditions. 

I have NEVER been told to " go away and don't bother coming back. " TWICE

In both cases, I had not even begun haggling. I just asked what is the best price you can offer, and then proceeded to say okay, I'll come back. 

The sore shopkeepers both said " I'm not going to sell it to you!! " 

Lol, their loss.

I went on to buy from a shop keeper that had the patience and the gusto to make a sale 😀

Thanks

364056305.name: Fun, dirty, smelly...must go here if you\'re in TJ.
364056305.author: a TripAdvisor user
364056305.reviewBody: Fun place to walk around, people watch and just hang out. Lots of craziness going on so it might not be for everybody.

363700467.name: I was there for a surgical procedure
363700467.author: a TripAdvisor user
363700467.reviewBody: everyone was very friendly.  Loved the shopping and spent lots of money.  Got fabulous gifts to bring home!  oh I also got some inhalers that were super inexpensive and work as well as our expensive ones from the USA

362688112.name: Lively & diverse!
362688112.author: a TripAdvisor user
362688112.reviewBody: Up and down the clean streets there are shops full of traditional Mexican arts & crafts, modern stores, art galleries (usually tucked away in the alleys - where a new wave of cutting edge people, visual & performing arts, book stores, coffee shops, & eateries commune.) Back on the avenida there are more excellent choices of restaurants & clubs, with musicians inside and out!

361821062.name: Not what it used to be but slowly recovering
361821062.author: a TripAdvisor user
361821062.reviewBody: Iconic boulevard of broken dreams...used to be the spot to get forbidden alcoholic beverages during the Depression.  Then it became the place for quick marriages and divorces.  It had its day as a street lined with strip joints and XXX shows. Later it became a strip of pharmacies to get low-cost meds.  Now, it\'s a jumble of throw-back curio shops, trendy foodie destinations (La Justina, Colectivo 9), iconic survivors (Caesar\'s, Chiki-Hai, Vittorio\'s), zonkeys to take pictures with, etc.  As foreign tourism dropped off in the recent past, Avenida Revoluci\u00f3n has had to reinvent itself yet again and it\'s succeeding in doing so again.  Folks of a certain age might remember alcohol-fueled Spring Breaks here but now the avenue is for the most part a popular destination for locals (which makes it more interesting, imho, and a fun place for foreigners to visit).

361738406.name: The heart of TJ
361738406.author: a TripAdvisor user
361738406.reviewBody: It\'s all happening at the Avenida Revolucion. My visit was action packed, with the avenue a hive of activity. Mariachi bands playing music, people dancing and singing, volumes of great Mexican fare being cooked in all corners and a very busy shopping strip make for fun visit to TJ.
